short_description: Implements the canopy algorithm for clustering data points.
long_description: Canopy clustering is a simple, fast, accurate method for grouping objects into preliminary clusters. It is often performed in preparation for more rigorous clustering techniques, such as The canopy clustering algorithm uses a fast approximate distance metric and two distance thresholds, T For distance measurement, the Canopy function uses Euclidean distance. If there are more than 10,000 canopy centers, the function fails. Run the function again, increasing the value of T 2 (specified by the TightDistance argument). The canopy clustering algorithm is nondeterministic, and the randomness of the canopy assignments cannot be controlled by a seed argument (for more information, see Nondeterministic Results).

input_tables.name: InputTable
input_tables.rDescription: Specifies the name of the table that contains the data to be clustered.
input_tables.description: Specifies the name of the table that contains the data to be clustered.

argument_clauses.name: LooseDistance
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the maximum distance that any point can be from a canopy center to be considered part of that canopy
argument_clauses.description: Specify the maximum distance that any point can be from a canopy center to be considered part of that canopy (T 1 ).

argument_clauses.name: TightDistance
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the minimum distance that separates two canopy centers.
argument_clauses.description: Specify the minimum distance that separates two canopy centers (T 2 ).

argument_clauses.name: SequenceInputBy
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the LIST_VECTOR of column(s) that uniquely identifies each row of the input argument INPUT_ARG_NAME. The argument is used to ensure deterministic results for functions which produce results that vary from run to run.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the input column(s) that uniquely identify each row of input table. The format is 'input1:c1' where input1 refers to the alias used by the input table that contains such column named c1.
